title: Between 1 January 2018 and 31 December 2018, will an armed group from Pakistan engage in a campaign that systematically kills 1,000 or more civilians in Pakistan?
preds: Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Integer nec odio. Praesent libero. Sed cursus ante dapibus diam. Sed nisi. Nulla quis sem at nibh elementum imperdiet. No chance. That's a lot of people.

I don't think they would be able to get away with a campaign that does that to the point of over 1,000 civilian deaths. I believe that outside actors would intervene before that point, especially when looking at the above definition of "systematically."
Taliban get stronger in these region
The Pakistani Army seems to tamped down the TTP for the moment. Here, suppressive campaigns by security forces are the most likely cause of mass civilian deaths.

The security situation in Pakistan is stable as far as safety for Pakistani citizens is concerned. There are no groups new or old making any type of advances or destabilizing the region, even in the Federal Administered Tribal Areas (FATA). While it is a terror hotbed, it is a stable one and the groups that have significant influence would not allow any deviance from that stability. I leave my answer as high as 5% because of ISIS' presence in their "Khorasan Province" just across the border in Afghanistan, and there is a chance that they could do something violent and crazy as their parent organization did in Iraq and Syria, but there have not been massacres in Afghanistan and it is highly unlikely there will start to be, or that there would be some that spilled over into Afghanistan. They know that the Taliban is too dug in in the area and they would not tolerate violence against themselves and their families, and neither would the Pakistani government.

Currently, the international community including the US has been putting pressure on Pakistan for not doing much and "harboring terrorists."  While this pressure might result in some horrible actions, I don't see any indication violence will occur outside of the odd curveball. The people of Pakistan, in a thriving democracy, would rather oust their leaders than see much violence.
This country is enigmatic in its behaviours and the internal conflicts are opaque- so not impossible in my mind

Such an event is most likely should tensions continue to grow over Tehreek-i-Labaik Ya Rasool Allah Pakistan protests. It is exceptionally unlikely that a civilian government would risk political blow back from religious groups, however if a coup were to occur (in response to government in action) then action might occur.

Keeping it low at 1%. Believe the IB more interested in making $ and keeping to low level engagements (Tribal Areas, Afghanistan, and Punjab). I haven’t heard much about relations between IB and Americans under Trump...
The slave trade has never stopped, sad to say.
In response to USA withholding financial support. Government stages mass causality Terrorism Incident.
As Pak tries to adjust their posture with the US there will be a lot more infighting and their trained rebels will agitate more internally vs externally.

Combined efforts of the Haqqani Network and Taliban fomented by ISI will likely end in a series of murders, bombings, attacks, etc. involving churches, mosques, public gatherings, smaller Islamic sects totalling at least 1,000.
As the Trump administration cuts off military aid to Pakistan the likelihood that terrorism expands in Pakistan increases as the government has less resources.
1000 deaths doesn’t serve Haqqani, China, USA, India, or Pakistani leadership. Could change but currently a stretch...

Although there are a lot of extremist groups in Pakistan, it is not very likely that any of them or the pakistani military will launch a violent campaign - the risks for the extremist groups are way too high, whereas the military "suffers" from buckling politicians, when there is small signs of protest.
If the notion is true that the grants to ISI and the Paks are to protect their nuclear arsenal and stabilize the gov't, then I would expect to see an uptick in violence.

Pakistan's government and military, while perhaps authoritarian by our standards, nevertheless have been dealing with armed conflict of one sort or another (think India, various military groups on the boarder with Afghanistan, coups within the country) for decades.  I think it highly unlikely that any campaign that would go on long enough to kill that many people before being stopped. My probability score is based on the overall regional instability causing something to happen.

We are cutting aid to Pakistan, over terrorism and the Jerusalem vote, and we have long heard that we maintained our support for them to prevent worse things from happening than we have already seen in the interim. If that was the case than we should expect the death count to go up, bit if the threat was hollow there will be no change.
Pakistan is the go to place that supports the dog of religious extremist it wont bit the hand that feeds it.
Pakistan wonâ€™t tolerate it without U.S. funding.
When looking at the situation for Shiites, particularly in Balochistan, the answer is pretty much yes.
